title: Arco Viaggio vs Arco Nano
comparison_headline: How portable does your espresso really need to be?
comparison_intro: The Viaggio is a fully manual, hand-powered espresso maker that weighs 340 grams and fits in a jacket pocket. The Nano is an ultra-compact electric machine that makes genuine espresso on a countertop. One goes anywhere. The other needs a plug but asks less of you.
hero_image_alt: Arco Viaggio manual espresso maker and Arco Nano electric machine, the Viaggio shown on a worn leather travel journal with a camping mug, the Nano on a minimal kitchen shelf, both in matte black, natural window light, illustrating the contrast between travel and home use

boiler_type.product_a: None — fully manual, no electricity required

heat_up_time.product_a: N/A — uses pre-heated water from a kettle or thermos

pressure_control.product_a: Hand pressure — up to 9 bar with proper technique, variable by nature
pressure_control.product_b: 15 bar pump (9 bar at group), fixed

steam_capability.product_b: Panarello-style steam wand for basic frothing

grind_compatibility.product_a: Requires pre-ground coffee or a hand grinder — forgiving of grind inconsistency
grind_compatibility.product_b: Works with any electric grinder; 54 mm portafilter

suitable_for.product_a: Travellers, campers, hotel room brewers, and anyone who wants espresso where there is no electricity
suitable_for.product_b: Small kitchens, secondary stations, and anyone who wants electric convenience in the smallest possible footprint

not_suitable_for.product_a: Anyone who wants consistency without technique — the Viaggio is only as good as the person using it
not_suitable_for.product_b: Anyone who actually needs to travel with their espresso setup — the Nano needs mains power and a stable surface

traveller.rationale: Nothing else we make fits in a carry-on — the Viaggio is the only option for genuine espresso in a hotel room, a campsite, or a mountain hut.

morning-minimalist.rationale: The Nano plugs in and heats up in 45 seconds — the Viaggio demands a kettle, hand-grinding, and technique that doesn't match a calm morning routine.

non-barista.rationale: The Nano automates the hard part — the Viaggio requires you to generate pressure by hand, which takes practice to do well.

craft-barista.rationale: For an experienced barista, the Viaggio's hand-pressure control is part of the appeal — it's espresso stripped to its essential physics.

verdict: These are not really competing products — they solve different problems. If you need espresso where there is no plug, the Viaggio is remarkable for what it achieves at 340 grams. If you want the smallest possible electric espresso machine for a permanent spot in your kitchen, the Nano delivers more consistency with less effort. Many of our customers own both.
